steps: Cool the burn under cool (not cold) running water for at least 10 minutes
Remove any jewelry or tight clothing near the burn area
Cover the burn with a clean, non-stick bandage or cloth
Do not break any blisters that form
Take over-the-counter pain relief if needed
Seek medical attention for severe burns or if the burn covers a large area
Burn.warning: Do not use ice, butter, or ointments on burns. For severe burns, seek immediate medical help.

steps: If someone is about to faint, help them lie down and elevate their legs
Loosen any tight clothing
Ensure they have fresh air
Once conscious, have them sit up slowly
Offer water if they're alert
If they don't regain consciousness quickly, call for emergency medical help
Faint.warning: If the person doesn't regain consciousness within a minute, call emergency services immediately.

steps: For adults: Stand behind the person and place your hands just above their navel
Make a fist with one hand and grasp it with the other
Perform quick, upward thrusts (Heimlich maneuver)
Continue until the object is expelled or the person becomes unconscious
For unconscious person: Call emergency services and begin CPR if trained
For children: Use gentler back blows and chest thrusts
Choking.warning: Call emergency services immediately if the person cannot breathe, speak, or cough. For children under 1 year, use different techniques - consult medical guidance.

steps: Apply direct pressure to stop the bleeding using a clean cloth or bandage
Clean the wound gently with cool running water
Apply an antibiotic ointment if available
Cover with a sterile bandage or gauze
Change the bandage daily and watch for signs of infection
Seek medical attention if the cut is deep, won't stop bleeding, or shows signs of infection
Cut.warning: For deep cuts or severe bleeding, apply pressure and seek immediate medical attention.

steps: Have the person sit down and lean slightly forward
Pinch the soft part of the nose (below the bone) for 10-15 minutes
Breathe through the mouth
Do not tilt the head back (this can cause blood to go down the throat)
Apply a cold compress to the bridge of the nose
If bleeding continues after 20 minutes, seek medical attention
Nosebleed.warning: If the nosebleed is severe or doesn't stop after 20 minutes of pressure, seek medical help.

steps: Rest the injured area and avoid putting weight on it
Apply ice wrapped in a cloth for 15-20 minutes, several times a day
Compress the area with an elastic bandage (not too tight)
Elevate the injured limb above heart level when possible
Take over-the-counter pain relief if needed
Seek medical attention if there's severe pain, inability to move the joint, or if symptoms worsen
Sprain.warning: If you suspect a broken bone (severe pain, deformity, inability to move), seek immediate medical attention.

steps: Move to a cool, shaded area or air-conditioned room
Lie down and elevate legs
Remove tight or unnecessary clothing
Cool the body with cool, wet cloths or a cool bath
Drink cool water or sports drinks (avoid caffeine or alcohol)
Seek medical attention if symptoms persist or worsen
Heat Exhaustion.warning: If symptoms progress to heat stroke (confusion, loss of consciousness, high body temperature), call emergency services immediately.

steps: Apply a cold compress or ice pack wrapped in a cloth to the area
Elevate the injured area if possible
Rest the affected area
After 48 hours, apply warm compresses to help with healing
Take over-the-counter pain relief if needed
Most bruises heal on their own within 1-2 weeks
Bruise.warning: Seek medical attention if the bruise is very large, painful, or appears after a serious injury.
